runnableItem.name: Intronserter
runnableItem.shortDescription: Intronserter is a tool for transgene optimization for nuclear expression in Chlamydomonas reinhardtii.
runnableItem.description:

Intronserter
- a tool for
systematic integration
of
introns
into
transgenes.
This tool was developed to provide a user-friendly platform for the design of optimized intron-containing transgenes.
runnableItem.customContent:
Incorporation of regulatory introns into cDNA has been shown in numerous eukaryotes to improve relative expression levels of transgenes. In the model green microalga
Chlamydomonas reinhardtii, spreading of introns systematically throughout a transgene to minimize exon lengths has been shown necessary to enable robust expression from its nuclear genome.
This webtool provides a step-by-step service for full codon optimization and intron spreading in target transgenes to remove the guess-work from gene design.
See the
Manual
to find out how it works.
Note that gene synthesis of the optimized DNA sequence is necessary.
Please cite in your materials and methods section:
"The sequence was optimized based on the strategy described in Baier et al, 2018, with the tool described in Jaeger et al, 2019." (see References)

input.description: User defined codon usage table, supplied in the standard codon usage table format / in NCBI's standard genetic code definition, found for instance at Kazusa or HIVE-CUT . For an example, click on the corresponding button below.

input.name: DNA sequence
input.description: DNA sequence in FASTA format into which introns are inserted by Intronserter. Note that by using this option, only step 3 = intron insertion is performed, and step 1 (codon optimization), step 2 (cut site removal) and step 4 (fine tuning) are skipped. This is intentionally done to leave your input DNA sequence untouched, i.e. to assure that your input DNA sequence, which might have been optimized by other means, e. g. for optimal mRNA structure, is not altered by Intronserter, except for intron insertion. For an example, click on the corresponding button below.

param.name: If "--custom--" was chosen, remove additional user defined restriction digest recognition sites
param.shortDescription: Enter any number of DNA sequences, separated by comma, e.g. "TCTAGA,CTCGAG" (just the comma-separated sequences, without any line breaks). Note that the length of each sequence must be of either 6 or 8 nt. Note further that this parameter is only active when "--custom--" was chosen above.
param.description: If "--custom--" was chosen as a restriction digest site to be removed, use this parameter to supply your restriction digest recogition sites that should be removed from the DNA sequence. Note that the length of each recognition sequence must be of either 6 or 8 nt; other lengths are not supported.

param.description: Start region exon length for automatic insertion (lesser equals) (see figure 2 above).

param.description: Target exon length for automatic insertion (about) (see figure 2 above).

param.name: Supersede automatic intron insertion process
param.shortDescription: If the checkbox below is activated, the automatic intron position determination is switched off. Instead, the positions supplied on the rigth are used. This is useful for other species, for instance when only one single intron at the end of the sequences should be inserted.
param.description: This parameter is to force the utilization of a manual intron position list. If activated, the automatic intron position determination is switched off and the supplied positions are used instead. This is useful for other species, for instance when only one single intron at the end of the sequences should be inserted.

param.name: User defined intron insertion position list
param.shortDescription: Supply any number of positions (in nt coordinates), separated by comma, where introns will be inserted. Entering for instance "100,550,1000,1450" will introduce four introns at the defined positions - of course only if the above defined nucleotide pair, e.g. "G^G", is found at these positions; otherwise, the positions are slightly varied until the defined nucleotide pair is found. Note that this parameter is only active if the checkbox on the left is activated.
param.description: If manually provided positions should be used instead, forced by the parameter "Supersede automatic intron insertion process", the positions defined here are used instead. Positions have to supplied as a comma-separated list of integer values. Note that the positions have to be provided in nt coordinates, not in amino acid coordinates. Note further that the positions might not be matched exactly, but only approximately, which is the case when the nucleotide pair, e.g. "G^G", cannot be found at these positions.

param.name: Intron sequence to be inserted
param.shortDescription: Enter the DNA sequence that should be used for each intron (just the sequence, without any line breaks). Note that the default is the *first* intron of rbcS2 of C. reinhardtii.
param.description: The intron sequence that is inserted into the cDNA sequence. The default is the first intron of rbcS2 of C. reinhardtii (or briefly, rbcS2i1).

param.name: Optional: substitute the last intron for the below defined second sequence
param.shortDescription: Activate this checkbox to substitue the last intron for a second sequence, e.g. to substitute the last intron for rbcS2 intron 2. Don't forget to specify the DNA sequence of the last intron below.
param.description: Use this option to substitute the last intron for a different intron sequence, such as the second intron of rbcS2 of C. reinhardtii (or briefly, rbcS2i2). This option is recommend in C-terminal fusions in the pOptimized vector toolkit (see Baier et al, 2018), and for other vectors (see figure 3 above).

param.name: If "substitute last intron" was activated, user defined last intron sequence
param.shortDescription: Enter the DNA sequence of the last intron (just the sequence, without any line breaks). Note that this parameter is only active if the checkbox above is active. Note further that the default is the *second* intron of rbcS2 of C. reinhardtii.
param.description: Intron DNA sequence of the last intron, if it should be substituted. The default is the second intron of rbcS2 of C. reinhardtii.

param.name: DNA sequence input - only insert introns
param.shortDescription: Activate this checkbox to only perform step 3 (insert introns), and skip step 1 (codon optimization), step 2 (cut site removal) and step 4 (fine tuning).
param.description: Use this option to only insert introns (step 3), and not do any other optimzation steps. With this option, codon optimzation (step 1), cut site removal (step 2) and fine-tuning (step 4) are not performed.

param.name: User defined nucleotide addition (DNA)
param.shortDescription: Enter a single DNA sequence, e.g. the recognition site "GGATCC", that should be inserted at the start / 5'-end. Leave empty if no nucleotides should be added. Note that this parameter is only active if "--custom--" was chosen on the left.
param.description: User defined nucleotide addition of any length that will be introduced at the 5'-end, such as a restriction digest recognition site, e.g. "GGATCC".

param.name: Start codon insertion
param.shortDescription: Activate this checkbox to insert a heading start codon (ATG, amino acid M) at the start / 5'-end.
param.description: Use this option to insert a heading start codon (ATG, amino acid M) at the 5'-end of the sequence.

param.name: Linker peptide (amino acid sequence)
param.shortDescription: Enter a single AA sequence, e.g. the linker "GSGS", that should be inserted at the start / 5'-end. Leave empty if no linker peptide should be added.
param.description: User defined amino acid sequence of any length that will be introduced at the 5'-end, such as the peptide linker "GSGS". Note that the additionally introduced amino acids are considered during the intron insertion process.

param.name: Start codon removal
param.shortDescription: Activate this checkbox to remove the native start codon (M, Met) of the input sequence.
param.description: Use this option to remove the native "start codon" (M, Met) of the input amino acid sequence.

param.name: Remove stop codon
param.shortDescription: Activate this checkbox to remove the native * stop codon of the input sequence. Note that this parameter is automatically activated if you request a linker peptide at the 3'-end.
param.description: Use this option to remove the native "stop codon" (*) of the input amino acid sequence. Note that this option is automatically activated if you request a linker peptide at the 3'-end, in order to avoid accidental premature translation termination.

param.name: Linker peptide (amino acid sequence)
param.shortDescription: Enter a single AA sequence, e.g. the linker "GSGS", that should be appended to the 3'-end. Leave empty if no linker peptide should be added.
param.description: User defined amino acid sequence of any length that will be appended to the 3'-end, such as the peptide linker "GSGS". Note that the additionally introduced amino acids are considered during the intron insertion process.

param.name: Stop codon insertion
param.shortDescription: Activate this checkbox to append a stop codon (TAA, TGA or TAG, amino acid *) at the 3'-end. Note that this parameter is ignored if you request a linker peptide at the 3' end.
param.description: Use this option to append a trailing stop codon (TAA, TGA or TAG, amino acid *) at the 3'-end of the sequence. Note that this option is ignored if you request a linker peptide at the 3'-end, in order to avoid accidental premature translation termination.

param.name: User defined nucleotide addition (DNA)
param.shortDescription: Enter a single DNA sequence, e.g. the recognition site "GGATCC", that should be appended to the 3'-end. Leave empty if no nucleotides should be added. Note that this parameter is only active if "--custom--" was chosen on the left.
param.description: User defined nucleotide addition of any length that will be appended to the 3'-end, such as a restriction digest recognition site, e.g. "GGATCC".

manual.introductoryText:
Welcome to
Intronserter - a tool for built to aid the design of
intron-containing
optimized transgenes for enhanced nuclear expression.
Intronserter was developed primarily for
Chlamydomonas reinhardtii, where systematic intron spreading into transgenes is necessary to enable robust expression from the nuclear genome. However, the Intronserter platform is fully customizable to any other target organism by enabling user-defined inputs such as codon tables and intron sequences. By default, this tool provides full codon optimization and intron spreading to encourage design of optimized transgenes for maximal expression from the eukaryotic algal nuclear genome.
The strategy has been successfully applied in
C. reinhardtii with numerous examples in literature:
Yunus, I.S., Wichmann, J., Wrdenweber, R., Lauersen, K.J., Kruse, O., Jones, P.R., 2018. Synthetic metabolic pathways for photobiological conversion of CO2 into hydrocarbon fuel. Metab. Eng. 49, 201?211. doi:10.1016/j.ymben.2018.08.008
Baier, T., Kros, D., Feiner, R.C., Lauersen, K.J., Mller, K.M., Kruse, O., 2018. Engineered Fusion Proteins for Efficient Protein Secretion and Purification of a Human Growth Factor from the Green Microalga Chlamydomonas reinhardtii. ACS Synth. Biol. 7, 2547?2557. doi:10.1021/acssynbio.8b00226
Baier, T., Wichmann, J., Kruse, O., Lauersen, K.J., 2018. Intron-containing algal transgenes mediate efficient recombinant gene expression in the green microalga Chlamydomonas reinhardtii. Nucleic Acids Res. 46, 6909?6919. doi:10.1093/nar/gky532
Lauersen, K. J., Wichmann, J., Baier, T., Kampranis, S. C., Pateraki, I., Mller, B. L., Kruse, O. (2018). Phototrophic production of heterologous diterpenoids and a hydroxy-functionalized derivative from Chlamydomonas reinhardtii. Metablic Engineering. doi:10.1016/j.ymben.2018.07.005
Wichmann, J., Baier, T., Wentnagel, E., Lauersen, K. J., Kruse, O. (2017). Tailored carbon partitioning for phototrophic production of (E)-?-bisabolene from the green microalga Chlamydomonas reinhardtii. Metabolic Engineering 45, 211-222. doi:10.1016/j.ymben.2017.12.010
Lauersen K. J., Baier T., Wichmann J., Wrdenweber R., Hbner W., Huser T., Kruse O. (2016). Efficient phototrophic production of a high-value sesquiterpenoid from the eukaryotic microalga Chlamydomonas reinhardtii. Metabolic Engineering 38, 331-343. doi:10.1016/j.ymben.2016.07.013.
The intron spreading strategy used for engineering nuclear transgene expression with
C. reinhardtii may also enhance transgene expression in other species, especially in other green algae. Therefore, Intronserter was designed so that all input parameters can be adjusted to fit any desired host. However, the enhancing effect of regulatory introns should be investigated first in other species, and the strategy outlined in Baier et al, 2018, might assist in this process.
Intronserter starts from an input amino acid sequence, and yields its optimized (codon-optimized and intron-enriched) DNA sequence counterpart, which is ready for gene synthesis, as outlined below:
Figure 1: Outline of Intronserter.
Towards this goal, Intronserter performs four steps:
1. Back translation of the Amino Acid (AA) sequence using the most frequent codon for AA.
2. Removal of restriction digest sites, so that, by default, restriction sites are avoided which are used in pOptimized and MoClo vector kits.
3. Enriching the cDNA sequence with introns to maximize expression (here, the regulatory intron "rbcS2 intron 1" is used, as it has been shown to boost transgene expression in C. reinhardtii (see Baier et al, 2018).
4. Optional fine tuning of the resulting DNA sequence to add for instance a linker peptide for fusions.
Step 3, the process of intron insertion, can be further dissected into three sub-steps:
3.1 Determination of intron positions:
3.1.1 Determination of putative intron insertion positions, based on the set of the four parameters "start, target, max and end".
3.1.2. At these position, the nucleotide pair, e.g. "G^G", where the intron is inserted, is searched.
3.2. The supplied intron DNA sequence is inserted between the two bases given by nucleotide pair, i. e., between G^G.
3.3. As a optional last step, the last intron can be substituted for another intron sequence, in order to maximize transgene expression in certain scenarios.
This process is outlined below:
Figure 2: Intron insertion process.
Step 3.3., the optional substitution of the last intron for "rbcS2 intron 2", is recommended in C-terminal fusions in the pOptimized vector toolkit (see Baier et al, 2018), and for other vectors:
Figure 3: Scenarios in which substitution of the last intron for rbcS2i2, instead of using rbcS2i1 only, is recommended.
Step 4, the optional fine tuning of the optimized sequence, has the following ordering:
Figure 4: Ordering of the options for sequence fine tuning.
Below, the individual parameters are explained in more detail.
